subdepartment.name: History of Art and Visual Culture

majors.majorname: History of Art and Visual Culture B.A.

electives.specialrequirement: At least five must be upper-division, and up to one lower-division course is allowed. At least two electives must be from the list of designated courses focusing on phenomena outside of the U.S. or on transnational or hemispheric subjects. At least one elective must be from the list of designated courses focusing on social movements. At least two academic divisions must be represented in the elective coursework.

lowerdiv.name: At least one lower-division survey course within their chosen region of concentration

upperdiv: Four additional courses in the region of concentration, at least three of which must be upper-division.

classes: Two courses from each of the remaining two regions of concentration.
One upper-division history course from any of the three regions of concentration.

courses: complete five quarters of language study at UC Santa Cruz

classes: three upper-division elective courses in linguistics

lowerdiv: Language studies majors must achieve a level of competency equivalent to six quarters in the language of concentration.
upperdiv: One advanced language course after level 6 is required for students concentrating in French, German, Italian, or Spanish. Majors in Chinese and Japanese must take two advanced language courses after level 6, the second of which (and any subsequent) counts toward the cultural context course requirement.

lowerdiv: Basic language proficiency: One year (three quarters or equivalent) of college-level study of a non-English language

classes: Two upper-division courses on literature written before 1750.
One upper-division course on non-Western literature or literature in a global perspective.
One upper-division course on poetry and poetics (may not be a creative writing course).
A senior seminar (a course in the LIT 190 series) or a senior thesis (LIT 195), which satisfies the campus comprehensive requirement (see below).

lowerdiv: At least one other course numbered below PHIL 100A, with the exception of PHIL 8

courses: Two courses numbered PHIL 100A or above

electives.specialrequirement: No more than two of the five can be from CMPM 131, CMPM 132, CMPM 150, CMPM 177, CSE 103, CSE 104 or ECON 166A. (These seven courses focus on other skills useful in computer game development, such as design, production, and mathematical analysis.)

classes.name: Elective
courses: Any 5-credit upper-division course offered by the Baskin School of Engineering, except for the DC courses CSE 115A and CSE 185E/CSE 185S.

electives.specialrequirement: Four courses must be completed from the list below . At least one course must be a computer science and engineering course. At most two courses can be from applied mathematics, statistics or mathematics, of which at most one may be substituted with two physics classes, chosen from the following list of class pairs: PHYS 6A and PHYS 6C, PHYS 6A and PHYS 6B, PHYS 5A and PHYS 5C, PHYS 5A and PHYS 5B. Any laboratories required or recommended by the Physics Department associated with these classes are not part of the computer science B.S. major requirements.

classes.name: Elective
courses: Any CSE course with a number below 170, or between 180 and 189, except for the DC courses CSE 115A and CSE 185E/CSE 185S.

electives.specialrequirement: In addition to completing the courses required for both concentrations, electrical engineering majors must complete four elective courses chosen from the lists below. Students pursuing the Electronics/Optics concentration must choose at least three courses from the Electronics/Optics courses listed below. Students pursuing the Communications,  Signals and Systems concentration must choose at least three courses from the Communication and Signals courses listed below. Design Elective: One of the four concentration courses chosen must include at least one of the following design electives ECE 118, ECE 157 & ECE 157L, ECE 121, and ECE 173. This course must be taken before the first capstone course ECE 129A.
Three to five from economic, up to two from business management, up to one from business management two
At least one of the four courses must be selected from List 1 below. In addition, two more courses must be taken from List 2 below.

A total of seven upper-division electives (environmental studies courses numbered ENVS 101 through ENVS 179) must be completed. One course must be from the list below of upper-division courses based on natural sciences, and one course must be from the list below of upper-division courses based on the social sciences.

The remaining six upper-division elective courses include three in ecology and evolutionary biology (ecology and evolutionary biology courses numbered BIOE 107-BIOE 188) and three in environmental studies (environmental studies courses numbered ENVS 101-ENVS 179).One of the six electives must be a laboratory course; laboratory courses are upper-division courses in BIOE or ENVS that carry 5 credits and have a “L” in their course number. Additionally, one of the three environmental studies courses electives must be based in the social sciences

requiredcourses.specialrequirement: For upperdiv: two courses from one group, one course from a second group, and one course from a third group

classes: One upper-division course outside of psychology from: Anthropology Community Studies Critical Race and Ethnic Studies Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Economics Education Environmental Studies  Feminist Studies History of Consciousness Latin American and Latino Studies Legal Studies Linguistics Philosophy  Politics Sociology Or a specific course from the list below: CMPM 146 CMPM 148 CSE 104 CSE 140 STAT 131 STAT 132 STAT 162
One of the upper-division courses must be an upper-division seminar

classes.name: Interdisciplinary Electives
classes.specialrequirement: Students must complete four interdisciplinary electives from lists of courses pre-approved by the Psychology Department, at least one of which must be upper-division. The electives fall into four groups: Evolution; Artificial Intelligence and Human-Computer Interaction; Linguistics; Philosophy. Three of the four electives must be selected from the same group. Students are responsible for planning their course of study to complete any necessary prerequisites for electives they wish to take. Possible sequences of interdisciplinary courses, including prerequisites, are given below.
